refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 12 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Preface

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 12.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The influence of the earthly life of Jesus our Saviour appears on every feature of nature, in every phase of human experience, in every fact of life. We can never fully realize how deep is the impression, how widespread is the influence, of the life of Jesus of Nazareth. Every blessing of every kind comes to us through that connection between heaven and earth which was formed when the Lord of glory espoused the cause of a world lost in sin.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 12.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The infinite pathos of that story has inspired the pen of the learned and the tongue of the eloquent. But it is best told in childlike language. The wonderful spectacle needs no human coloring. Its glory surpasses the art of men. It shines brightest in its own luster.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 12.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In these pages no effort is made toward artificial embellishment. The plain story, as told by one who is moved by a deep sense of the infinite proportions of the subject, has been put into the language of the young. In its simplicity not only does it speak to the hearts of the young, but it meets the desire expressed by us all in the familiar song—

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 13 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 1—The Birth of Jesus

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 13.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In the little town of Nazareth, nestled among the hills of Galilee, was the home of Joseph and Mary, who were afterward known as the earthly parents of Jesus.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 13.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Now Joseph was of the lineage, or family, of David; and so, when a decree was sent out for the people to be taxed, he had to go to Bethlehem, the city of David, to have his name enrolled. This was a toilsome journey, as people traveled in those times. Mary, who went with her husband, was very weary as she climbed the hill on which Bethlehem stands.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 13.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: How she longed for a comfortable place in which to rest! But the inns were already full. The rich and proud were well cared for, while these humble travelers had to find rest in a rude building where cattle were sheltered.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 13.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Joseph and Mary possessed little of earth's riches, but they had the love of God, and this made them rich in contentment and peace. They were children of the heavenly King, who was about to give them a wonderful honor.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 13.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Angels had been watching them while they were on their journey, and when night came on, and they went to rest, they were not left alone. Angels were still with them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 15.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: There, in that lowly shed, Jesus the Saviour was born and laid in a manger. In that rude cradle lay the Son of the Highest—He whose presence had filled the courts of Heaven with glory.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 15.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Before He came to the earth, Jesus was the Commander of the angel hosts. The brightest and most exalted of the sons of the morning heralded His glory at the creation. They veiled their faces before Him as He sat upon His throne. They cast their crowns at His feet, and sang His triumphs as they beheld His greatness.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 15.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Yet this glorious Being loved the poor sinner, and took upon Him the form of a servant, that He might suffer and die for us.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 15.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus might have remained at the Father's side, wearing the kingly crown and the royal robe; but for our sake He chose to exchange the riches of Heaven for the poverty of earth.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 15.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He chose to leave His station of high command, to leave the angels who loved Him. The adoration of the heavenly throng He chose to exchange for mockery and abuse by wicked men. From love to us, He accepted a life of hardship and a death of shame.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 15.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: All this Christ did to show how much God loves us. He lived on earth to show how we may honor God by obedience to His will. He did this so that by following His example we may at last dwell with Him in His heavenly home.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 15.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The priests and rulers among the Jews were not ready to welcome Jesus. They knew that the Saviour was soon to come, but they expected Him to be a mighty king who would make them rich and great. They were too proud to think of the Messiah as being a helpless child.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 16.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So when Christ was born, God did not reveal it to them. He sent the glad news to some shepherds who kept their flocks on the hills around Bethlehem.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 16.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: These were good men, and as they watched their sheep by night, they talked together about the promised Saviour, and prayed so earnestly for His coming that God sent bright messengers from His own throne of light to teach them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 16.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And, lo, the angel of the Lord came upon them, and the glory of the Lord shone round about them: and they were sore afraid.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 16.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And the angel said unto them, Fear not: for, behold, I bring you good tidings of great joy, which shall be to all people. For unto you is born this day in the city of David a Saviour, which is Christ the Lord.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 16.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And this shall be a sign unto you; Ye shall find the babe wrapped in swaddling clothes, lying in a manger.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 16.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And suddenly there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host praising God, and saying, Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good will toward men.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 16.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And it came to pass, as the angels were gone away from them into heaven, the shepherds said one to another, Let us now go even unto Bethlehem, and see this thing which is come to pass, which the Lord hath made known unto us.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 16.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And they came with haste, and found Mary, and Joseph, and the babe lying in a manger. And when they had seen it, they made known abroad the saying which was told them concerning this child.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 16.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And all they that heard it wondered at those things which were told them by the shepherds. But Mary kept all these things, and pondered them in her heart.” Luke 2:9-19.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 17 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 2—Jesus Presented in the Temple

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 17.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Joseph and Mary were Jews, and followed the customs of their nation. When Jesus was six weeks old, they brought Him to the Lord in the temple at Jerusalem.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 17.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This was according to the law which God had given to Israel, and Jesus was to be obedient in all things. So God's own Son, the Prince of Heaven, by His example teaches that we should obey.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 17.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Only the first-born son of each family was thus presented at the temple. This ceremony was to keep in memory an event that had taken place long before.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 17.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When the children of Israel were slaves in Egypt, the Lord sent Moses to set them free. He bade Moses go to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and say:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 17.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Thus saith the Lord, Israel is My son, even My firstborn: and I say unto thee, Let My son go, that he may serve Me: and if thou refuse to let him go, behold, I will slay thy son, even thy firstborn.” Exodus 4:22, 23.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 17.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Moses carried this message to the king. But Pharaoh's answer was, “Who is the Lord, that I should obey His voice to let Israel go? I know not the Lord, neither will I let Israel go.” Exodus 5:2.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 18.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Then the Lord sent fearful plagues upon the Egyptians. The last of these plagues was the slaying of the first-born son of every family, from that of the king to the lowliest in the land.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 18.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Lord told Moses that every family of the Israelites must kill a lamb, and put some of the blood upon the door-posts of their dwellings.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 18.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This was a sign, that the angel of death might pass over all the houses of the Israelites, and destroy none but the proud and cruel Egyptians.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 18.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This blood of the “Passover” represented to the Jews the blood of Christ. For in due time, God would give His dear Son to be slain as the lamb had been slain; so that all who should believe in Him might be saved from everlasting death. Christ is called our Passover. (1 Corinthians 5:7.) By His blood, through faith, we are redeemed. (Ephesians 1:7.)

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 18.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So as each family in Israel brought the eldest son to the temple, they were to remember how the children had been saved from the plague, and how all might be saved from sin and eternal death. The child presented at the temple was taken in the arms of the priest, and held up before the altar.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 18.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Thus it was solemnly dedicated to God. Then after it was given back to the mother, its name was written in the roll, or book, that contained the names of the first-born of Israel. So all who are saved by Christ's blood will have their names written in the book of life.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 19.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Joseph and Mary brought Jesus to the priest as the law required. Every day fathers and mothers were coming with their children, and in Joseph and Mary the priest saw nothing different from many others. They were simply working people.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 19.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In the child Jesus he saw only a helpless infant. Little did the priest think that he was then holding in his arms the Saviour of the world, the High Priest of the heavenly temple. But he might have known; for if he had been obedient to God's Word, the Lord would have taught him these things.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 19.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At this very time there were in the temple two of God's true servants, Simeon and Anna. Both had grown old in His service, and He showed them things that could not be made known to the proud and selfish priests.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 19.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: To Simeon had been given the promise that he should not die until he had seen the Saviour. As soon as he saw Jesus in the temple, he knew that this was the promised One.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 19.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Upon the face of Jesus there was a soft, heavenly light; and Simeon, taking the child in his arms, praised God, and said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 19.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Lord, now lettest Thou Thy servant depart in peace, according to Thy word: for mine eyes have seen Thy salvation, which Thou hast prepared before the face of all people; a light to lighten the Gentiles, and the glory of Thy people Israel.” Luke 2:29-32.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 19.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Anna, a prophetess, “coming in that instant gave thanks likewise unto the Lord, and spake of Him to all them that looked for redemption in Jerusalem.” Luke 2:38.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 19.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So it is that God chooses humble people to be His witnesses. Often those whom the world calls great are passed by. Many are like the Jewish priests and rulers.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 20.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Many are eager to serve and honor themselves, but think little about serving and honoring God. Therefore He cannot choose them to tell others of His love and mercy.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 20.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Mary, the mother of Jesus, pondered the far-reaching prophecy of Simeon. As she looked upon the child in her arms, and recalled what the shepherds of Bethlehem had said, she was full of grateful joy and bright hope.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 20.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Simeon's words called to her mind the prophecy of Isaiah. She knew that of Jesus were spoken these wonderful words:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 20.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “The people that walked in darkness have seen a great light: they that dwell in the land of the shadow of death, upon them hath the light shined.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 20.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “For unto us a child is born, unto us a Son is given: and the government shall be upon His shoulder: and His name shall be called Wonderful, Counsellor, the Mighty God, the Everlasting Father, the Prince of Peace.” Isaiah 9:2, 6.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 21 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 3—The Visit of the Wise Men

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 21.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: God wanted the people to know about the coming of Christ to the earth. The priests should have taught the people to look for the Saviour; but they themselves did not know of His coming.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 21.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So God sent angels to tell the shepherds that Christ was born, and where they might find Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 21.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So, too, when Jesus was presented at the temple, there were those who received Him as the Saviour. God had preserved the lives of Simeon and Anna, and they had the joyful privilege of testifying that Jesus was the promised Messiah.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 21.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: God meant for others, as well as the Jews, to know that Christ had come. In a country far to the east were wise men who had studied the prophecies concerning the Messiah, and who believed that His coming was near.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 21.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Jews called these men heathen; but they were not idolaters. They were honest men, who wanted to know the truth, and to do the will of God.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 21.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: God looks upon the heart, and He knew that these men could be trusted. They were in a better condition to receive light from Heaven than were the Jewish priests, who were so full of selfishness and pride.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 23.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: These wise men were philosophers. They had studied the handiwork of God in nature, and had learned to love Him there. They had studied the stars, and knew their movements.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 23.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They loved to watch the heavenly bodies in their nightly march. If a new star should be seen, they would welcome its appearance as a great event.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 23.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: On that night when the angels came to the shepherds of Bethlehem, the wise men had noticed a strange light in the sky. It was the glory which surrounded the angel host.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 23.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When this light faded away, they had seen in the heavens what looked like a new star. At once they thought of the prophecy which says, “There shall come a Star out of Jacob, and a Sceptre shall rise out of Israel.” Numbers 24:17. Was this star a sign that the Messiah had come? They determined to follow it, and see where it would lead them. It led them into Judea. But when they came near to Jerusalem, the star grew so dim that they could not follow it.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 23.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Supposing that the Jews could at once guide them to the Saviour, the wise men went into Jerusalem, and said, “Where is He that is born King of the Jews? For we have seen His star in the east, and are come to worship Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 23.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “When Herod the king had heard these things, he was troubled, and all Jerusalem with him. And when he had gathered all the chief priests and scribes of the people together, he demanded of them where Christ should be born. And they said unto him, In Bethlehem of Judea: for thus it is written by the prophet.” Matthew 2:2-5.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 23.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Herod did not like to hear of a king who might some day take his throne. So he took the wise men by themselves, and asked when they first saw the star. Then he sent them to Bethlehem, saying: “Go and search diligently for the young child; and when ye have found Him, bring me word again, that I may come and worship Him also.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 24.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When the wise men heard this, they started again on their journey. “And, lo, the star, which they saw in the east, went before them, till it came and stood over where the young child was.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 24.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “When they were come into the house, they saw the young child with Mary His mother, and fell down, and worshiped Him: and when they had opened their treasures, they presented unto Him gifts; gold, and frankincense, and myrrh.” Matthew 2:6-11.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 24.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The most precious things they had, the wise men brought to the Saviour. In this they set an example for us. Many give presents to their earthly friends, but have none for the heavenly Friend who has given them every blessing. We should not do this. To Christ we should bring the best of all we have—of our time, money, and our love.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 24.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: We may give to Him by giving to comfort the poor, and to teach people about the Saviour. So we can help to save those for whom He died. Such gifts Jesus blesses.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 25 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 4—The Flight Into Egypt

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 25.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Herod had not been honest in saying that he wanted to go and worship Jesus. He feared that the Saviour would grow up to be a king, and take his kingdom from him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 25.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He wanted to find the child, that he might have Him put to death.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 25.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The wise men prepared to return and tell Herod. But the angel of the Lord appeared to them in a dream, and sent them home another way.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 25.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And when they were departed, behold, the angel of the Lord appeareth to Joseph in a dream, saying, Arise, and take the young child and His mother, and flee into Egypt, and be thou there until I bring thee word: for Herod will seek the young child to destroy Him.” Matthew 2:13.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 25.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Joseph did not wait till morning; he rose at once, and with Mary and the child, started by night on the long journey.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 25.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The wise men had given costly presents to Jesus, and in this way God provided for the expenses of the journey and their stay in Egypt, until they should return to their own land.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 27.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Herod was very angry when he found that the wise men had gone home another way. He knew what God by His prophet had said about Christ's coming.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 27.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He knew how the star had been sent as a guide to the wise men. Yet he was determined to destroy Jesus. In his wrath he sent soldiers to kill “all the children that were in Bethlehem, ... from two years old and under.” Matthew 2:16.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 27.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: How strange that a man should fight against God! What an awful scene this slaying of the innocent children must have been! Herod had before done many cruel things; but his wicked life was soon to end. He died a terrible death.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 27.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Joseph and Mary remained in Egypt till after the death of Herod. Then the angel appeared to Joseph, and said, “Arise, and take the young child and His mother, and go into the land of Israel: for they are dead which sought the young child's life.” Matthew 2:20.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 27.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Joseph had hoped to make his home in Bethlehem, where Jesus was born; but on coming near to Judea, he learned that a son of Herod was reigning in place of his father.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 27.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This made Joseph afraid to go there, and he did not know what to do; so God sent an angel to instruct him. Following the directions of the angel, Joseph returned to his old home in Nazareth.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 29 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 5—Child Life of Jesus

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 29.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus in His childhood lived in a little mountain village. He was the Son of God, and He might have had any place on earth for His home.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 29.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He would have been an honor to any place. But He did not go to the homes of rich men or the palaces of kings. He chose to dwell among the poor in Nazareth.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 29.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus wants the poor to know that He understands their trials. He has borne all that they have to bear. He can sympathize with them and help them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 29.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Of Jesus in His early years the Bible says, “The child grew, and waxed strong in spirit, filled with wisdom: and the grace of God was upon Him.” “And Jesus increased in wisdom and stature, and in favor with God and man.” Luke 2:40, 52.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 29.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: His mind was bright and active. He was of quick understanding, and showed a thoughtfulness and wisdom beyond His years. Yet His ways were simple and childlike, and He grew in mind and body as other children grow.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 29.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But Jesus was not in all things like other children. He always showed a sweet, unselfish spirit. His willing hands were always ready to serve others. He was patient and truthful.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 30.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Firm as a rock in standing for the right, He never failed to be gentle and courteous toward all. In His home, and wherever He might be, He was like a cheerful sunbeam.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 30.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He was thoughtful and kind toward the aged and the poor, and He showed kindness even to the dumb animals. He would care tenderly for a little wounded bird, and every living thing was happier when He was near.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 30.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In the days of Christ the Jews gave much care to the education of their children. Their schools were connected with the synagogues, or places of worship, and the teachers were called rabbis, men who were supposed to be very learned.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 30.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus did not go to these schools, for they taught many things that were not true. Instead of God's Word, the sayings of men were studied, and often these were contrary to that which God had taught through His prophets.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 30.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: God Himself by His Holy Spirit instructed Mary how to bring up His Son. Mary taught Jesus from the Holy Scriptures, and He learned to read and study them for Himself.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 30.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus also loved to study the wonderful things which God had made, in the earth and in the sky. In this book of nature He saw the trees and plants and animals, and the sun and the stars.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 30.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Day by day He watched them, and tried to learn lessons from them, and to understand the reason of things.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 30.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Holy angels were with Him, and helped Him to learn from these things about God. Thus, as He grew in height and strength, He grew also in knowledge and wisdom.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 30.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Every child may gain knowledge as Jesus did. We should spend our time in learning only that which is true. Falsehood and fables will do us no good.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 31.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Only the truth is of any value, and this we may learn from God's Word and from His works. As we study these things the angels will help us to understand.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 31.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: We shall see the wisdom and goodness of our heavenly Father. Our minds will be strengthened, our hearts will be made pure, and we shall be more like Christ.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 31.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Every year Joseph and Mary went up to Jerusalem, to the feast of the Passover. When Jesus was twelve years old, they took Him with them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 31.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This was a pleasant journey. The people traveled on foot, or rode on oxen or asses, and it took several days to go. The distance from Nazareth to Jerusalem is about seventy miles. From all parts of the land, and even from other countries, the people went to this feast, and those from the same place usually traveled together, in a large company.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 31.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The feast was held near the close of March or the beginning of April. This was springtime in Palestine, and the whole land was bright with flowers, and glad with the song of birds.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 31.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As they traveled, parents told their children of the wonderful things that God had done for Israel in ages past. And often they sang together some of the beautiful psalms of David.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 31.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In the days of Christ the people had grown cold and formal in their service to God. They thought more of their own pleasure than of His goodness to them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 31.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But it was not so with Jesus. He loved to think about God. As He came to the temple, He watched the priests in their work. He bowed with the worshipers as they knelt to pray, and His voice joined in the songs of praise.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 32.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Every morning and evening a lamb was offered upon the altar. This was to represent the death of the Saviour. As the child Jesus looked upon the innocent victim, the Holy Spirit taught Him its meaning. He knew that He Himself, as the Lamb of God, must die for the sins of men.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 32.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: With such thoughts in His mind, Jesus wanted to be alone. So He did not stay with His parents in the temple, and when they started for home He was not with them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 32.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In a room connected with the temple there was a school taught by the rabbis, and to this place after a while the child Jesus came. He sat with the other youth at the feet of the great teachers, and listened to their words.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 32.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Jews had many wrong ideas about the Messiah. Jesus knew this, but He did not contradict the learned men. As one who wished to be taught, He asked questions about what the prophets had written.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 32.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The fifty-third chapter of Isaiah speaks of the Saviour's death, and Jesus read this chapter, and asked its meaning.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 32.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The rabbis could give no answer. They began to question Jesus, and they were astonished at His knowledge of the Scriptures.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 32.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They saw that He understood the Bible far better than they did. They saw that their teaching was wrong, but they were not willing to believe anything different.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 32.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Yet Jesus was so modest and gentle that they were not angry with Him. They wanted to keep Him as a student, and teach Him to explain the Bible as they did.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 32.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When Joseph and Mary left Jerusalem on their journey toward home, they did not notice that Jesus stayed behind. They thought that He was with some of their friends in the company.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 33.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But on stopping to camp for the night, they missed His helpful hand. They looked for Him throughout the company, but in vain.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 33.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Joseph and Mary were in great fear. They remembered how Herod had tried to kill Jesus in His infancy, and they were afraid that some evil had now befallen Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 33.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: With sorrowful hearts they hastened back to Jerusalem; but it was not till the third day that they found Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 33.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Great was their joy at seeing Him again, yet Mary thought that He was to blame for leaving them. She said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 33.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Son, why hast Thou thus dealt with us? Behold, Thy father and I have sought Thee sorrowing.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 33.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “How is it that ye sought Me?” Jesus answered. “Wist ye not that I must be about My Father's business?” Luke 2:48, 49.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 33.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As He spoke these words, Jesus pointed upward. On His face was a light at which they wondered. Jesus knew that He was the Son of God, and He had been doing the work for which His Father had sent Him into the world.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 33.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Mary never forgot these words. In the years that followed, she better understood their wonderful meaning.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 33.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Joseph and Mary loved Jesus, yet they had been careless in losing Him. They had forgotten the very work which God had given them to do. By one day's neglect they lost Jesus.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 33.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In the same way today many lose the Saviour from their company. When we do not love to think about Him, or pray to Him; when we speak idle, unkind, or evil words, we separate ourselves from Christ. Without Him, we are lonely and sad.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 34.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But if we really desire His company, He will always be with us. With all who seek His presence, the Saviour loves to stay. He will brighten the poorest home, and gladden the lowliest heart.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 34.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Though He knew that He was the Son of God, Jesus went home to Nazareth with Joseph and Mary. Until thirty years of age He was “subject unto them.” Luke 2:51.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 34.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He who had been the Commander of Heaven was on earth a loving and obedient son. The great things brought to His mind by the service of the temple were hidden in His heart. He waited until God's time to begin His appointed work.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 34.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus lived in the home of a peasant, a poor man. Faithfully and cheerfully He did His part in helping to support the family. As soon as He was old enough, He learned a trade, and worked in the carpenter's shop with Joseph.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 34.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In the coarse dress of a common laborer He passed through the streets of the little town, going to and from His work. He did not use His divine power to make His life easier for Himself.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 34.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As Jesus worked in childhood and youth, He grew strong in body and mind. He tried to use all His powers in such a way as to keep them in health, that He might do the best work in every line.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 34.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Whatever He did was done well. He wanted to be perfect, even in the handling of tools. By His example He taught that we ought to be industrious, that we should do our work carefully and well, and that such work is honorable. All should find something to do that will be helpful to themselves and to others.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 35.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: God gave us work as a blessing, and He is pleased with children who cheerfully take their part in the duties of the household, sharing the burdens of father and mother. Such children will go out from the home to be a blessing to others.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 35.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The youth who try to please God in all that they do, who do right because it is right, will be useful in the world. By being faithful in a humble place they are fitting themselves for a higher position.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 37 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 6—Days of Conflict

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 37.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Jewish teachers made many rules for the people, and required them to do many things that God had not commanded. Even the children had to learn and obey these rules. But Jesus did not try to learn what the rabbis taught. He was careful not to speak disrespectfully of these teachers, but He studied the Scriptures, and obeyed the laws of God.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 37.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Often He was reproved for not obeying what others did. Then He showed from the Bible what was the right way.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 37.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus was always trying to make others happy. Because He was so kind and gentle, the rabbis hoped to make Him do as they did. But they could not. When urged to obey their rules He asked what the Bible taught. Whatever that said, He would do.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 37.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This made the rabbis angry. They knew that their rules were contrary to the Bible, and yet they were displeased with Jesus for refusing to obey them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 37.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They complained of Him to His parents. Joseph and Mary thought the rabbis good men, and Jesus suffered blame, which was hard to bear.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 38.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The brothers of Jesus took sides with the rabbis. The words of these teachers, they said, should be heeded as the word of God. They reproved Jesus for setting Himself above the leaders of the people.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 38.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The rabbis thought themselves better than other men, and they would not associate with the common people. The poor and ignorant they despised. Even the sick and suffering they left without hope or comfort.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 38.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus showed a loving interest in all men. Every suffering one whom He met, He tried to help. He had little money to give, but He often denied Himself of food in order to help others.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 38.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When His brothers spoke harshly to poor, wretched beings, Jesus would go to these very ones and speak words of kindness and encouragement.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 38.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: To those who were hungry and thirsty, He would bring a cup of cold water, and often would give them the food intended for His own meal.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 38.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: All this displeased His brothers. They threatened and tried to terrify Him, but He kept right on, doing as God had said.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 38.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Many were the trials and temptations that Jesus had to meet. Satan was always watching to overcome Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 38.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: If Jesus could have been led to do one wrong act, or to speak one impatient word, He could not have been our Saviour, and the whole world would have been lost. Satan knew this, and it was for this reason that he tried so hard to lead Jesus into sin.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 38.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour was always guarded by heavenly angels, yet His life was one long struggle against the powers of darkness. Not one of us will ever have to meet such fierce temptations as He did.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 39.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But to every temptation He had one answer: “It is written.” The wrongdoing of His brothers He did not often rebuke, but He told them what God had said.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 39.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Nazareth was a wicked town, and the children and youth tried to have Jesus follow their evil ways. He was bright and cheerful, and they liked His company.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 39.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But His godly principles roused their anger. Often for refusing to join in some forbidden act, He was called a coward. Often He was sneered at, as being altogether too particular about little things. To all this His answer was: “It is written.” “The fear of the Lord, that is wisdom; and to depart from evil is understanding.” Job 28:28. To love evil is to love death, for “the wages of sin is death.” Romans 6:23.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 39.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus did not contend for His rights. When roughly used, He bore it patiently. Because He was so willing and uncomplaining, His work was often made needlessly hard. Yet He was not discouraged for He knew that God smiled upon Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 39.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: His happiest hours were found when alone with nature and with God. When His work was done, He loved to go into the fields, to meditate in the green valleys, to pray to God on the mountainside, or amid the trees of the forest.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 39.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He listened to the lark caroling forth music to its Creator, and His voice joined the song of joyful praise and thanksgiving.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 39.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: With the voice of singing He welcomed the morning light. The break of day often found Him in some quiet place, thinking about God, studying the Bible, or in prayer.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 40.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: From these peaceful hours He would return to His home to take up His duties again, and to give an example of patient toil. Wherever He was, His presence seemed to bring the angels near. The influence of His pure, holy life was felt by all classes of people.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 40.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Harmless and undefiled, He walked among the thoughtless, the rude, the uncourteous; amid the unjust taxgatherers, the reckless prodigals, the unrighteous Samaritans, the heathen soldiers, and the rough peasants.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 40.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He spoke a word of sympathy here, and a word there, as He saw men weary, yet compelled to bear heavy burdens. He shared their burdens, and repeated to them the lessons He had learned from nature, of the love, the kindness, the goodness of God.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 40.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He taught them to look upon themselves as having precious talents, which if rightly used would gain for them eternal riches. By His own example He taught that every moment of time is of value, and should be put to some good use.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 40.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He passed by no human being as worthless, but tried to encourage the roughest and most unpromising. He told them that God loved them as His children, and that they might become like Him in character.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 40.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So in a quiet way Jesus from His very childhood worked for others. This work none of the learned teachers, nor even His own brothers, could make Him give up. With an earnest purpose He carried out the design of His life, for He was to be the light of the world.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 41 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 7—The Baptism

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 41.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When the time for Christ's public ministry had come, His first act was to go to the river Jordan, and be baptized by John the Baptist.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 41.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: John had been sent to prepare the way for the Saviour. He had preached in the wilderness, saying:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 41.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “The kingdom of God is at hand: repent ye, and believe the gospel.” Mark 1:15.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 41.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Multitudes flocked to hear him. Many were convicted of their sins, and were baptized by him in the Jordan.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 41.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: God had made known to John that some day the Messiah would come to him and ask to be baptized. He had also promised that a sign should be given him, so that he might know who it was.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 41.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When Jesus came, John saw in His face such signs of His holy life, that he forbade Him, saying: “I have need to be baptized of Thee, and comest Thou to me?

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 41.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And Jesus answering said unto him, Suffer it to be so now: for thus it becometh us to fulfil all righteousness.” Matthew 3:14, 15.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 42.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: And as He said this, there was seen upon His face the same heavenly light that Simeon had beheld.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 42.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So John led the Saviour down into the waters of the beautiful Jordan, and there he baptized Him in the sight of all the people.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 42.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus was not baptized to show repentance for His own sins; for He had never sinned. He did it to set an example for us.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 42.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When He came up out of the water, He kneeled on the riverbank, and prayed. Then the heavens were opened, beams of glory streamed forth, “and He saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove, and lighting upon Him.” Matthew 3:16.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 42.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: His face and form were all aglow with the light of the glory of God. And from Heaven the voice of God was heard saying:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 42.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “This is My beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.” Matthew 3:16, 17.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 42.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The glory that rested upon Christ was a pledge of the love of God for us. The Saviour came as our example; and just as surely as God heard His prayer, He will hear ours.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 42.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The most needy, the most sinful, the most despised, may find access to the Father. When we come to Him in Jesus’ name, the voice which spoke to Jesus speaks to us, saying; “This is My beloved child, in whom I am well pleased.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 43 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 8—The Temptation

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 43.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: After His baptism, Christ was led by the Spirit into the wilderness, to be tempted of the devil.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 43.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In going into the wilderness, Christ was led by the Spirit of God. He did not invite temptation. He wanted to be alone, that he might contemplate His mission and work.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 43.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: By prayer and fasting He was to brace Himself for the bloodstained path He must travel. But Satan knew where the Saviour had gone; so he went there to tempt Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 43.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As Christ left the Jordan, His face was lighted with the glory of God. But after He entered the wilderness, this glory disappeared.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 43.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The sins of the world were upon Him, and His face showed such sorrow and anguish as man had never felt. He was suffering for sinners.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 43.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Adam and Eve in Eden had disobeyed God by eating of the forbidden fruit. Their disobedience had brought sin and sorrow and death into the world.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 43.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ came to give an example of obedience. In the wilderness, after fasting forty days, He would not, even to obtain food, depart from the will of His Father.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 45.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: One of the temptations that overcame our first parents was the temptation to indulge appetite. By this long fast Christ was to show that appetite can be brought under control.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 45.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Satan tempts men to indulgence, because this weakens the body and beclouds the mind. Then he knows that he can the more easily deceive and destroy them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 45.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But Christ's example teaches that every wrong desire must be overcome. Our appetites are not to rule us; we must rule them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 45.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When Satan first appeared to Christ, he looked like an angel of light. He claimed to be a messenger from Heaven.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 45.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He told Jesus that it was not the will of His Father that He should endure this suffering; He was to show only a willingness to suffer.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 45.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When Jesus was struggling against the keenest pangs of hunger, Satan said to Him:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 45.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “If Thou be the Son of God, command that these stones be made bread.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 45.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But since the Saviour had come to live as our example, He must endure suffering as we have to endure it; He must not work a miracle for His own good. His miracles were all to be for the good of others. To the demand of Satan He answered:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 45.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “It is written, Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 45.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Thus He showed that it is far less important to provide ourselves with food than that we should obey the word of God. Those who obey God's word have the promise of all things needed for the present life, and they have also the promise of future life.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 46.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Satan had failed to overcome Christ in the first great temptation; he next carried Him to a pinnacle of the temple at Jerusalem, and said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 46.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “If thou be the Son of God, cast Thyself down: for it is written, He shall give His angels charge concerning Thee: and in their hands they shall bear Thee up, lest at any time Thou dash Thy foot against a stone.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 46.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Satan here followed Christ's example in quoting Scripture. But this promise is not for those who willfully venture into danger. God had not told Jesus to throw Himself down from the temple. Jesus would not do it to please Satan. He said: “It is written again, Thou shalt not tempt the Lord thy God.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 46.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: We should trust in the care of our heavenly Father; but we must not go where He does not send us. We must not do what He has forbidden.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 46.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Because God is merciful, and ready to forgive, there are those who say that it is safe to disobey Him. But this is presumption. God will forgive all who seek pardon and turn away from sin. But those who choose to disobey Him He can not bless.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 46.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Satan now appeared what he really was—the prince of the powers of darkness. He took Jesus to the top of a high mountain, and showed Him all the kingdoms of the world.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 46.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The sunlight lay on splendid cities, marble palaces, fruitful fields, and vineyards. Satan said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 46.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “All these things will I give Thee, if Thou wilt fall down and worship me.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 47.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: For a moment Christ looked upon the scene. Then He turned away. Satan had presented the world to Him in the most attractive light; but the Saviour looked beneath the outward beauty.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 47.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He saw the world in its wretchedness and sin, apart from God. All this misery was the result of man's turning away from God to worship Satan.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 47.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ was filled with longing to redeem that which was lost. He longed to restore the world to more than its Eden beauty. He wanted to place men on vantage ground with God.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 47.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: For sinful man He was withstanding temptation. He was to be an overcomer, that they might overcome, that they might be equal with the angels, and be worthy to be acknowledged as sons of God.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 47.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: To Satan's demand for worship, Christ answered:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 47.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Get thee hence, Satan: for it is written, Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and Him only shalt thou serve.” Matthew 4:3-10.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 47.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The love of the world, the lust for power, and the pride of life—everything that draws man away from the worship of God—was embraced in this great temptation of Christ.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 47.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Satan offered Christ the world and its riches if He would pay homage to the principles of evil. So Satan presents to us the advantages to be gained by wrongdoing.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 47.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He whispers to us, “In order to succeed in this world, you must serve me. Do not be too particular about truth and honesty. Obey my counsel, and I will give you riches, honor, and happiness.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 47.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In obeying this counsel we are worshiping Satan instead of God. It will bring us only misery and ruin.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 48.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ has shown us what we should do when tempted.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 48.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When He said to Satan, “Get thee hence,” the tempter could not resist the command. He was compelled to go.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 48.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Writhing with baffled hate and rage, the rebel chief left the presence of the world's Redeemer.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 48.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The contest was ended for the time. Christ's victory was as complete as had been the failure of Adam.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 48.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So we may resist temptation, and overcome Satan. The Lord says to us, “Resist the devil, and he will flee from you. Draw nigh to God, and He will draw nigh to you.” James 4:7, 8.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 49 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 9—Early Ministry

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 49.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: From the wilderness, Christ returned to the Jordan, where John the Baptist was preaching. At that time men sent by the rulers at Jerusalem were questioning John as to his authority for teaching and baptizing the people.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 49.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They asked if he was the Messiah, or Elijah, or “that prophet,” meaning Moses. To all this he answered, “I am not.” Then they asked: “Who art thou? that we may give an answer to them that sent us.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 49.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “He said, I am the voice of one crying in the wilderness, Make straight the way of the Lord, as said the prophet Esaias.” John 1:22, 23.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 49.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In old times when a king had to travel from one part of his country to another, men were sent ahead of his chariot to prepare the roads.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 49.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They had to cut down trees, gather out the stones, and fill up the hollows, so that the way would be clear for the king.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 49.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So when Jesus, the heavenly King, was coming, John the Baptist was sent to prepare the way by telling the people, and calling on them to repent of their sins.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 50.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As John answered the messengers from Jerusalem, he saw Jesus standing on the riverbank. His face lighted up, and stretching out his hands, he said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 50.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “There standeth One among you, whom ye know not; He it is, who coming after me is preferred before me, whose shoe's latchet I am not worthy to unloose.” John 1:26, 27.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 50.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The people were greatly moved. The Messiah was among them! They looked about eagerly to find the One of whom John had spoken. But Jesus had mingled with the multitude, and was lost to sight.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 50.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The next day John again saw Jesus, and, pointing to Him, cried: “Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world!”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 50.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Then John told of the sign that had been seen at Christ's baptism. “I saw, and bare record,” he added, “that this is the Son of God.” John 1:29, 34.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 50.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: With awe and wonder the hearers looked upon Jesus. They questioned with themselves, Is this the Christ?

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 50.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They saw that Jesus bore no tokens of worldly wealth or greatness. His clothing was plain and simple, such as poor people wore. But in His pale, worn face was something that moved their hearts.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 50.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In that face they read dignity and power; and every glance of the eye, every feature of the countenance, spoke of divine compassion and unutterable love.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 50.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But the messengers from Jerusalem were not drawn to the Saviour. John had not said that which they desired to hear. They expected the Messiah to come as a great conqueror. They saw that this was not the mission of Jesus, and in disappointment they turned from Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 51.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The next day John again saw Jesus, and again he cried, “Behold the Lamb of God!” John 1:36. Two of John's disciples were standing near, and they followed Jesus. They listened to His teaching, and became His disciples. One of the two was Andrew, the other John.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 51.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Andrew soon brought to Jesus his own brother, Simon, whom Christ named Peter. The next day, on the way to Galilee, Christ called another disciple, Philip. As soon as Philip found the Saviour, he brought his friend Nathaniel.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 51.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In this way Christ's great work on earth was begun. One by one He called His disciples, and one brought his brother, another his friend. This is what every follower of Christ is to do. As soon as he himself knows Jesus, he is to tell others what a precious Friend he has found. This is a work that all can do, whether they are young or old.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 51.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At Cana in Galilee, Christ, with his disciples, attended a marriage feast. For the happiness of this household gathering, His wonderful power was put forth.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 51.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: It was the custom in that country to use wine on such occasions. Before the feast was ended, the supply of wine had failed. The lack of wine at a feast would be thought to show a want of hospitality, and this was regarded as a great disgrace.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 51.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ was told of what had happened, and He bade the servants fill six large stone jars with water. Then He said, “Draw out now, and bear unto the governor of the feast.” John 2:8.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 51.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Instead of water, there came forth wine. This wine was much better than that which had been served before, and there was enough for all.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 53.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: After working the miracle, Jesus quietly went away. Not till He had gone, did the guests know of the work He had done.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 53.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ's gift to the marriage feast was a symbol. The water represented baptism, and the wine His blood, that was to be shed for the world.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 53.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The wine which Jesus made was not fermented liquor. Such wine is a cause of drunkenness and many great evils, and God had forbidden its use. He says, “Wine is a mocker, strong drink is raging: and whosoever is deceived thereby is not wise.” “It biteth like a serpent, and stingeth like an adder.” Proverbs 20:1; 23:32.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 53.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The wine used at the feast was the pure, sweet juice of the grape. It was like that which the prophet Isaiah calls “the new wine in the cluster;” and he says, “A blessing is in it.” Isaiah 65:8.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 53.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: By going to the marriage feast, Christ showed that it is right to meet together in this pleasant way. He liked to see people happy. Often He visited them in their homes, and tried to have them forget their cares and their troubles, and think of God's goodness and His love. Wherever He might be, Christ was always trying to do this. Wherever a heart was open to receive the divine message, He unfolded the truths of the way of salvation.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 53.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: One day, as He was passing through the country of Samaria, He sat down by a well to rest. When a woman came to draw water, He asked her for a drink.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 53.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The woman wondered at this, for she knew how the Jews hated the Samaritans. But Christ told her that if she would ask of Him, He would give her living water. At this she wondered the more. Then Jesus said to her:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 55.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Whosoever drinketh of this water shall thirst again: but whosoever drinketh of the water that I shall give him shall never thirst; but the water that I shall give him shall be in him a well of water springing up into everlasting life.” John 4:13, 14. By the living water is meant the Holy Spirit. As a thirsty traveler needs water to drink, so do we need God's Spirit in our hearts. He who drinks of this water shall never thirst.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 55.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Holy Spirit brings God's love into our hearts. It satisfies our longings, so that the riches and honors and pleasures of this world do not attract us. And it fills us with such joy that we want others to have it too. It will be in us like a spring of water, that flows out in blessing to all around.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 55.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: And every one in whom God's Spirit dwells, will live forever with Christ in His kingdom. Received into the heart by faith, it is the beginning of the life eternal.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 55.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This precious blessing Christ told the woman He would give her if she asked for it. So He will give it to us.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 55.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This woman had broken God's commandments, and Christ showed her that He knew the sins of her life. But He showed, too, that He was her friend, that He loved and pitied her, and that if she was willing to forsake her sins, God would receive her as His child.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 55.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: How glad she was to know this! In her joy she hurried away to the town near by, and called the people to come and see Jesus.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 55.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So they came to the well, and asked Him to stay with them. He remained two days, and taught them, and many listened to His words. They repented of their sins, and believed on Him as their Saviour.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 56.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: During His ministry, Jesus twice visited His old home at Nazareth. At the first visit He went to the synagogue on the Sabbath day.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 56.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Here He read from Isaiah's prophecy about the work of the Messiah—how He was to preach good tidings to the poor, to comfort the sorrowing, to give sight to the blind, and to heal those that were bruised.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 56.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Then He told the people that all this was fulfilled that day. This was the work that He Himself was doing.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 56.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At these words the hearers were filled with joy. They believed that Jesus was the promised Saviour. Their hearts were moved upon by the Holy Spirit, and they responded with fervent amens and praises to the Lord.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 56.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Then they remembered how Jesus had lived among them as a carpenter. Often they had seen Him working in the shop with Joseph. Though in His whole life there had been only deeds of love and mercy, they would not believe that He was the Messiah.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 56.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: By such thoughts as these they opened the way for Satan to control their minds. Then they were filled with wrath against the Saviour. They cried out against Him, and determined to take His life.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 56.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They hurried Him away, meaning to throw Him over the steep side of a hill. But holy angels were near to protect Him. He passed safely through the crowd, and was not to be found.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 56.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The next time He came to Nazareth, the people were no more ready to receive Him. He went away, never to return.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 57.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ worked for those who wanted His help, and all through the country the people flocked about Him. As He healed and taught them, there was great rejoicing. Heaven seemed to come down to the earth, and they feasted upon the grace of a merciful Saviour.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 59 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 10—Teachings of Christ

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 59.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Among the Jews, religion had come to be little more than a round of ceremonies. As they had departed from the true worship of God, and lost the spiritual power of His word, they had tried to supply the lack by adding ceremonies and traditions of their own.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 59.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Only the blood of Christ can cleanse from sin. Only His power can keep men from sinning. But the Jews depended upon their own works and ceremonies of their religion to earn for them salvation. Because of their zeal for these ceremonies they thought themselves righteous, and worthy of a place in God's kingdom.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 59.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But their hopes were fixed on worldly greatness. They longed for riches and power, and these they expected as the reward for their pretended piety.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 59.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They looked for the Messiah to set up His kingdom on this earth, and to rule as a mighty prince among men. Every worldly blessing they hoped to receive at His coming.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 59.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus knew that their hopes were to be disappointed. He had come to teach them of something far better than they had sought.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 60.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He had come to restore the true worship of God. He was to bring in a pure heart religion, that would manifest itself in a pure life and a holy character.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 60.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In the beautiful Sermon on the Mount He explained what God thinks most precious, and what would give real happiness.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 60.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour's disciples had been influenced by the teachings of the rabbis; and for these disciples, first of all, Christ's lessons were spoken. That which He taught them is for us also. We need to learn the same things.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 60.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Blessed are the poor in spirit,” Christ said. Matthew 5:3. The poor in spirit are those who know their own sinfulness and need. They know that of themselves they can do no good thing. They desire help from God, and to them His blessing is given.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 60.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “For thus saith the high and lofty One that inhabiteth eternity, whose name is Holy; I dwell in the high and holy place, with him also that is of a contrite and humble spirit, to revive the spirit of the humble, and to revive the heart of the contrite ones.” Isaiah 57:15.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 60.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Blessed are they that mourn.” Matthew 5:4. This does not mean those who complain and murmur, and who go about with a sour, downcast look. It means those who are truly sorry for their sins, and who ask God for pardon.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 60.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: All such He will freely forgive. He says, “I will turn their mourning into joy, and will comfort them, and make them rejoice from their sorrow.” Jeremiah 31:13.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 60.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Blessed are the meek.” Matthew 5:5. Christ says, “Learn of Me; for I am meek and lowly in heart.” Matthew 11:29. When He was wrongfully treated, He returned good for evil. In this He has given us an example, that we should do as He has done.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 61.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness.” Righteousness is right-doing. It is obedience to the law of God; for in that law the principles of righteousness are set forth. The Bible says, “All Thy commandments are righteousness.” Psalm 119:172.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 61.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: That law Christ, by His example, taught men to obey. The righteousness of the law is seen in His life. We hunger and thirst after righteousness when we want to have all our thoughts, our words, and our actions, like Christ's.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 61.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: And we may be like Christ if we really desire to be. We may have our lives like His life, our actions in harmony with the law of God. The Holy Spirit will bring God's love into our hearts, so that we shall delight to do His will.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 61.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: God is more willing to give us His Spirit than parents are to give good things to their children. His promise is, “Ask, and it shall be given you.” Luke 11:9; Matthew 7:7. All that hunger and thirst after righteousness “shall be filled.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 61.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Blessed are the merciful.” Matthew 5:7. To be merciful is to treat others better than they deserve. So God has treated us. He delights to show mercy. He is kind to the unthankful and to the evil.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 61.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So He teaches us to treat one another. He says, “Be ye kind one to another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake hath forgiven you.” Ephesians 4:32.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 61.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Blessed are the pure in heart.” Matthew 5:8. God cares more for what we really are than for what we say we are. He does not care how beautiful we may look, but He wants our hearts pure. Then all our words and actions will be right.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 62.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: King David prayed, “Create in me a clean heart, O God.” “Let the words of my mouth, and the meditation of my heart, be acceptable in Thy sight, O Lord, my strength, and my Redeemer.” Psalm 51:10; 19:14. This should be our prayer.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 62.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Blessed are the peacemakers.” Matthew 5:9. He who has the meek and lowly spirit of Christ will be a peacemaker. Such a spirit provokes no quarrel, gives back no angry answer. It makes the home happy, and brings a sweet peace that blesses all around.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 62.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness’ sake.” Matthew 5:10. Christ knew that for His sake many of His disciples would be put in prison, and many would be killed. But He told them not to mourn because of this.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 62.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Nothing can harm those who love and follow Christ. He will be with them in every place. They may be put to death, but He will give them a life that will never end, and a crown of glory that fadeth not away.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 62.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: And from them others will learn about the dear Saviour. Christ said to His disciples:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 62.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Ye are the light of the world.” Matthew 5:14. Jesus was soon going away from the world to His heavenly home. But the disciples were to teach the people of His love. They were to be as lights among men.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 62.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The lamp in the lighthouse, shining out in the darkness, guides the ship safely to the harbor; thus Christ's followers are to shine in this dark world, to guide men to Christ and the heavenly home.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 63.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This is what all the followers of Christ are to do. He calls them to work with Him in saving others.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 63.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Such lessons were strange and new to Christ's hearers, and He repeated them many times. At one time a lawyer came to Him with the question: “Master, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?” Jesus said unto him, “What is written in the law? how readest thou?

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 63.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And he answering said, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind; and thy neighbor as thyself.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 63.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Thou hast answered right,” said Christ; “this do and thou shalt live.” The lawyer had not done this. He knew that he had not loved others as himself. Instead of repenting, he tried to find an excuse for his selfishness. So he asked Jesus: “Who is my neighbor?” Luke 10:25-29.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 63.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The priests and rabbis often disputed about this question. They did not call the poor and ignorant their neighbors, and would show them no kindness. Christ took no part in their disputes; He answered the question by a story about something that had happened a short time before.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 63.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: A certain man, He said, was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho. The road was steep and rocky, and passed through a wild, lonely region. Here the man was seized by robbers, and stripped of all that he had. He was beaten and bruised, and left for dead.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 63.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As he lay thus, a priest and then a Levite from the temple at Jerusalem came that way. But instead of helping the poor man, they passed by on the other side.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 65.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: These men had been chosen to minister in God's temple, and they ought to have been like Him, full of mercy and kindness. But their hearts were cold and unfeeling.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 65.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: After a time a Samaritan came near. The Samaritans were despised and hated by the Jews. To one of these people a Jew would not give so much as a drink of water or a morsel of bread. But the Samaritan did not stop to think of this. He did not stop even to think of the robbers who might be watching for him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 65.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: There lay the stranger, bleeding and ready to die. The Samaritan took off his own cloak, and wrapped it about him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 65.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He gave him his own wine to drink, and poured oil on his wounds. He put him on his own beast, brought him to an inn, and took care of him all night.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 65.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The next morning, before going away, he paid the innkeeper to care for him till he should be strong again. So Jesus told the story. Then turning to the lawyer, He asked:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 65.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Which now of these three, thinkest thou, was neighbor unto him that fell among the thieves?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 65.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The lawyer answered, “He that showed mercy on him.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 65.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Then Jesus said, “Go, and do thou likewise.” Luke 10:35-37. So Jesus taught that every person who needs our help is our neighbor. We are to treat him just as we ourselves would like to be treated.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 65.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The priest and the Levite pretended to keep God's commandments, but it was the Samaritan who really kept them. His heart was kind and loving.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 65.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In taking care of the wounded stranger, he was showing love to God as well as to man. For it pleases God to have us do good to one another. We show our love for Him by being kind to those about us.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 66.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: A kind, loving heart is worth more than all the riches in the world. Those who live to do good show that they are children of God. They are the ones who will dwell with Christ in His kingdom.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 67 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 11—Sabbathkeeping

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 67.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour kept the Sabbath, and taught His disciples to keep it. He knew how it should be kept, for He Himself had made it holy.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 67.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Bible says, “Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy.” “The seventh day is the Sabbath of the Lord thy God.” “For in six days the Lord made heaven and earth, the sea, and all that in them is, and rested the seventh day: wherefore the Lord blessed the Sabbath day, and hallowed it.” Exodus 20:8, 10, 11; 31:16, 17. Christ had worked with His Father in creating the earth, and He had made the Sabbath. The Bible says that “all things were made by Him.” John 1:3.
