refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 67.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When we look on the sun and the stars, the trees and the beautiful flowers, we should remember that Christ made them all. And He made the Sabbath to help us keep in mind His love and power.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 67.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Jewish teachers had made many rules about the way to keep the Sabbath, and they wanted every one to obey their rules. So they watched the Saviour, to see what He would do.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 69.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: One Sabbath, as Christ and His disciples were going home from the synagogue, they passed through a field of grain. It was late, and the disciples were hungry. So they broke off some of the heads of grain, rubbed them in their hands, and ate the kernels.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 69.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: On any other day, one passing through a field or an orchard was allowed to gather what he wanted to eat. But it was not so on the Sabbath. Christ's enemies saw what the disciples were doing, and they said to the Saviour:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 69.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Behold, Thy disciples do that which is not lawful to do upon the Sabbath day.” Matthew 12:2.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 69.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But Christ defended His followers. He reminded His accusers of David, who, when in need, had eaten of the sacred bread of the tabernacle, and had given it to his hungry followers.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 69.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: If it was right for David when hungry to eat this sacred bread, then was it not right for the disciples when hungry to pluck the grain on the sacred hours of the Sabbath?

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 69.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Sabbath was not made to be a burden to man. It was to do him good, to give him peace and rest. Therefore our Lord said, “The Sabbath was made for man, and not man for the Sabbath.” Mark 2:27.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 69.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And it came to pass also on another Sabbath, that He entered into the synagogue and taught: and there was a man whose right hand was withered.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 69.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And the scribes and Pharisees watched Him, whether He would heal on the Sabbath day; that they might find an accusation against Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 69.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “But He knew their thoughts, and said to the man which had the withered hand, Rise up, and stand forth in the midst. And he arose and stood forth.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 70.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Then said Jesus unto them, I will ask you one thing; Is it lawful on the Sabbath days to do good, or to do evil? to save life, or to destroy it?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 70.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And when He had looked round about on them with anger, being grieved for the hardness of their hearts, He saith unto the man, Stretch forth thine hand. And he stretched it out: and his hand was restored whole as the other.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 70.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And they were filled with madness; and communed one with another what they might do to Jesus.” Luke 6:6-9, 11; Mark 3:5.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 70.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour showed how unreasonable they were, by asking them a question. “And He said unto them, What man shall there be among you, that shall have one sheep, and if it fall into a pit on the Sabbath day, will he not lay hold on it, and lift it out?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 70.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This they could not answer. So He said, “How much then is a man better than a sheep? Wherefore it is lawful to do well on the Sabbath days.” Matthew 12:11, 12.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 70.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “It is lawful;” that is, it is according to law. Christ never reproved the Jews for keeping the law of God, or for honoring the Sabbath. On the contrary, He ever upheld the law in all its completeness.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 70.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Isaiah prophesied of Christ, “He will magnify the law, and make it honorable.” Isaiah 42:21. To magnify is to make larger, to raise to a higher position.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 70.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ magnified the law by showing in every part its wonderful meaning. He showed that it is to be obeyed, not only in the actions, which are seen by men, but in the thoughts, which are known only to God.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 70.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: To those who claimed that He came to set aside the law, He said, “Think not that I am come to destroy the law, or the prophets: I am not come to destroy, but to fulfil.” Matthew 5:17.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 71.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: To fulfill means to keep, or perform. (James 2:8.) So when He came to be baptized by John the Baptist, He said, “Thus it becometh us to fulfil all righteousness.” Matthew 3:15. To fulfill the law is to obey it perfectly.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 71.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: God's law can never be changed; for Christ said, “Till heaven and earth pass, one jot or one tittle shall in no wise pass from the law, till all be fulfilled.” Matthew 5:18.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 71.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When He asked the question, “Is it lawful on the Sabbath days to do good, or to do evil? to save life, or to destroy it?” Christ showed that He could read the hearts of the wicked Pharisees who accused Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 71.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: While He was trying to save life by healing the sick, they were trying to destroy life by putting Him to death. Was it better to slay upon the Sabbath, as they were planning to do, than to cure the suffering ones, as He had done?

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 71.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Was it better to have murder in the heart on God's holy day than to have love toward all men—love which is shown in kindness and deeds of mercy?

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 71.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Many times the Jews charged Christ with breaking the Sabbath. Often they tried to kill Him because He did not keep it according to their traditions. But this made no difference with Him. He kept the Sabbath as God wanted it to be kept.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 71.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In Jerusalem there was a large pool of water called Bethesda. At certain times this pool was troubled; the people believed that an angel of the Lord went down into it, and stirred the waters, and that the first one who stepped in after the waters were stirred would be cured of whatever disease he had.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 72.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Great numbers of people came to the place, hoping to be cured; but most of them were disappointed. At the moving of the waters there was such a crowd, that many could not even get to the edge of the pool.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 72.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: One Sabbath day Jesus came to Bethesda. His heart was filled with pity as He saw the poor sufferers there.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 72.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: One man seemed more wretched than the others. For thirty-eight years he had been a helpless cripple. No doctor could cure him. Many times he had been brought to Bethesda; but when the waters were troubled, another would step in before him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 72.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: On this Sabbath he had tried once more to reach the pool, but in vain. Jesus saw him as he crept back to the mat which was his bed. His strength was almost gone. Unless help should come soon, he must die.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 72.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As he lay thus, now and then lifting his eyes to look at the pool, a loving face bent over him, and he heard a voice say, “Wilt thou be made whole?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 72.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The man answered sorrowfully, “Sir, I have no man, when the water is troubled, to put me into the pool: but while I am coming, another steppeth down before me.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 72.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He did not know that the One beside him could heal, not one only, but all who should come to Him. Christ said to the man: “Rise, take up thy bed, and walk.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 72.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At once he tried to obey the command, and strength came to him. He sprang to his feet, and found that he could stand and could walk. What a delight it was!

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 72.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He took up his bed and hurried away, praising God at every step. Soon he met some of the Pharisees, and told them of his wonderful cure. They did not seem glad, but reproved him for carrying his bed on the Sabbath day. The man told them, “He that made me whole, the same said unto me, Take up thy bed, and walk.” John 5:1-11.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 73.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Then they were no longer displeased with him, but they blamed the one who had told him to carry his bed on the Sabbath day.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 73.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At Jerusalem, where the Saviour now was, many of the learned rabbis lived. Here their false ideas about the Sabbath were taught to the people. Great numbers came to worship at the temple, and thus the rabbis’ teaching was spread far and wide. Christ wished to correct these errors. This was why He healed the man on the Sabbath day, and told him to carry his bed. He knew that this act would attract the attention of the rabbis, and thus would give Him an opportunity to instruct them. So it proved. The Pharisees brought Christ before the Sanhedrin, the chief council of the Jews, to answer the charge of Sabbathbreaking.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 73.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour declared that His action was in harmony with the Sabbath law. It was in harmony with the will and the work of God. “My Father worketh hitherto,” He said, “and I work.” John 5:17.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 73.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: God works continually in sustaining every living thing. Was His work to cease upon the Sabbath day? Should God forbid the sun to fulfill its office on the Sabbath? Should He cut off its rays from warming the earth and nourishing vegetation?

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 73.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Should the brooks stay from watering the fields, and the waves of the sea still their ebbing and flowing? Must the wheat and maize stop growing, and the trees and flowers put forth no bud or blossom on the Sabbath?

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 74.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Then man would miss the fruits of the earth, and the blessings that sustain his life. Nature must continue her work, or man would die. And man also has a work to do on this day. The necessities of life must be attended to, the sick must be cared for, the wants of the needy must be supplied. God does not desire His creatures to suffer an hour's pain that may be relieved on the Sabbath or any other day.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 74.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Heaven's work never ceases, and we should never rest from doing good. Our own work the law forbids us to do on the rest day of the Lord. The toil for a livelihood must cease; no labor for worldly pleasure or profit is lawful upon that day. But the Sabbath is not to be spent in useless inactivity. As God ceased from His labor of creating, and rested upon the Sabbath, so we are to rest. He bids us lay aside our daily occupations, and devote those sacred hours to healthful rest, to worship, and to holy deeds.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 75 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 12—The Good Shepherd

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 75.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour spoke of Himself as a shepherd, and of the disciples as His flock. He said: “I am the Good Shepherd, and know My sheep, and am known of Mine.” John 10:14.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 75.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ was soon to leave His disciples, and He said this to give them comfort. When He should be no more with them, they would remember His words.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 75.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Whenever they saw a shepherd watching his flock, they would think of the Saviour's love and care for them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 75.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In that land the shepherd stayed with his flock day and night. Over the rocky hills and through the forests he led them by day, to pleasant, grassy fields by the riverside.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 75.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Through the night he watched them, guarding them from wild beasts and from robbers, that were often lurking near.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 75.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Tenderly He cared for the feeble and sickly ones. The little lambs He took in His arms, and carried in His bosom.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 75.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: However large the flock, the shepherd knew every sheep. He had a name for each, and called it by its name.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 75.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So Christ, the heavenly Shepherd, cares for His flock that is scattered throughout the world. He knows us all by name. He knows the very house in which we live, and the name of each inmate. He cares for each one as if there were not another in the whole world.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 76.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The shepherd went before his sheep, and met all the dangers. He encountered the wild beasts and the robbers. Sometimes the shepherd was killed while guarding his flock.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 76.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So the Saviour guards His flock of disciples. He has gone before us. He has lived on earth, as we live. He was a child, a youth, a man. He overcame Satan and all his temptations, so that we may overcome.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 76.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He died to save us. Though now He is in Heaven, He does not forget us for a moment. He will safely keep every sheep. Not one that follows Him can be taken by the great enemy.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 76.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: A shepherd might have a hundred sheep, but if one was missing he did not stay with those that were in the fold. He went to search for the lost one.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 76.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Out in the dark night, through the storm, over mountains and valleys, he would go. He would not rest till the sheep was found.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 76.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Then he took it in his arms, and carried it back to the fold. He did not complain of the long, hard search, but gladly said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 76.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Rejoice with me; for I have found my sheep which was lost.” Luke 15:4-7.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 76.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So the care of the Saviour-Shepherd is not for those only who are in the fold. He says, “The Son of man is come to save that which was lost.” Matthew 18:11.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 76.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “I say unto you, That likewise joy shall be in heaven over one sinner that repenteth, more than over ninety and nine just persons, which need no repentance.” Luke 15:7.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 77.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: We have sinned, and have wandered away from God. Christ says we are like the sheep that has wandered away from the fold. He came to help us live without sin. This He calls bringing us back to the fold.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 77.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When we return with the Shepherd, and cease to sin, Christ says to the angels in Heaven: “Rejoice with Me; for I have found My sheep which was lost.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 77.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: And a joyful anthem rings out from the angelic choir, filling all Heaven with richest melody.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 77.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ presents to us no picture of a sorrowful shepherd returning without the sheep. Here is a pledge that not even one of the straying sheep of God's fold is overlooked.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 77.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Not one is left unhelped. Every one that will submit to be ransomed, the Saviour will rescue from the wilds of sin.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 77.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Then let every wanderer from the fold take courage. The Good Shepherd is searching for you. Remember that His work is “to save that which was lost.” That means you.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 77.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: To doubt the possibility of your salvation is to doubt the saving power of Him who purchased you at an infinite cost. Let faith take the place of unbelief. Look at the hands that were pierced for you, and rejoice in their power to save.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 77.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Remember that God and Christ are interested in you, and that all the host of Heaven are engaged in the work for the salvation of sinners.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 77.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: While Christ was on earth, He showed by His miracles that He had power to save unto the uttermost. By curing the diseases of the body, He showed that He was able to take away sin from the heart.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 77.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He caused the lame to walk, the deaf to hear, and the blind to see. He cleansed the poor lepers, and healed the man with palsy, and those who had all kinds of diseases.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 79.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: By His word, even the devils were driven out from the ones whom they had been possessing. Those who saw this wonderful work were astonished, and said: “What a word is this! For with authority and power He commandeth the unclean spirits, and they come out!” Luke 4:36.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 79.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At the command of Jesus, Peter was able to walk on the water. But he had to keep his eyes on the Saviour. As soon as he looked away, he began to doubt and sink.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 79.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Then he cried, “Lord, save me,” and the Saviour's hand was stretched forth to lift him up. Matthew 14:28-31. So whenever one cries to Him for help, the hand of Christ is stretched forth to save.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 79.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour raised the dead to life. One of these was the widow's son at Nain. The people were carrying him to the grave, when they met Jesus. He took the young man by the hand, lifted him up, and gave him alive to his mother. Then the company went back to their homes with shouts of rejoicing and praise to God.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 79.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So also the daughter of Jairus was raised, and by Christ's word, Lazarus, who had been dead four days, was called forth from the tomb.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 79.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So when Christ shall come to earth again, His voice will pierce the tombs, and “the dead in Christ shall rise” to glorious, immortal life; and so shall they “ever be with the Lord.” 1 Thessalonians 4:16, 17.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 79.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: It was a wonderful work done by our Lord during His ministry on earth. Of this work He spoke in the answer He sent to John the Baptist. John was in prison, and had become despondent; he was even troubled by doubts as to whether Jesus was really the Messiah. So he sent some of his followers to ask the Saviour:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 80.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Art Thou He that should come, or do we look for another?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 80.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When the messengers came to Jesus, there were about Him many sick, whom He was healing. All day the messengers waited, while He worked with tireless activity to help the suffering ones. At last He said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 80.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Go and show John again those things which ye do hear and see: the blind receive their sight, and the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, and the deaf hear, the dead are raised up, and the poor have the gospel preached to them.” Matthew 11:3-5.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 80.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So, for three years and a half, Jesus “went about doing good.” Then the time came for His ministry on earth to be finished. With His disciples He must go up to Jerusalem to be betrayed, condemned, and crucified.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 80.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Thus were to be fulfilled His own words, “The Good Shepherd giveth His life for the sheep.” John 10:11.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 80.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Surely He hath borne our griefs, and carried our sorrows.... He was wounded for our transgressions, He was bruised for our iniquities: the chastisement of our peace was upon Him; and with His stripes we are healed. All we like sheep have gone astray; we have turned every one to his own way; and the Lord hath laid on Him the iniquity of us all.” Isaiah 53:4-6.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 83 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 13—Riding Into Jerusalem

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 83.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus was nearing Jerusalem to attend the Passover. He was surrounded by multitudes who were also going up to this great yearly feast.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 83.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At His command, two of the disciples brought an ass's colt that He might ride into Jerusalem. They spread their garments upon the beast, and placed their Master upon it.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 83.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As soon as He was seated, a loud shout of triumph rent the air. The multitude hailed Him as Messiah, their King. More than five hundred years before, the prophet had foretold this scene:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 83.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Zion; ... behold, thy King cometh unto thee; ... lowly, and riding upon an ass, and upon a colt the foal of an ass.” Zechariah 9:9.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 83.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: All in the rapidly increasing throng were happy and excited. They could not offer Him costly gifts, but they spread their outer garments, as a carpet, in His path.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 83.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They broke off the beautiful branches of the olive and the palm, and strewed them in the way. They thought they were escorting Christ to take possession of the throne of David in Jerusalem.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 84.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour had never before allowed His followers to show Him kingly honors. But at this time He desired especially to manifest Himself to the world as its Redeemer.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 84.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Son of God was about to become a sacrifice for the sins of men. His church in all succeeding ages must make His death a subject of deep thought and study. It was necessary, then, that the eyes of all people should now be directed to Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 84.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: After such a scene as this, His trial and crucifixion could never be hidden from the world. It was God's design that each event in the closing days of the Saviour's life should be so plainly marked that no power could cause it to be forgotten.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 84.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In the vast multitude surrounding the Saviour were the evidences of His miracle-working power.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 84.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The blind whom He had restored to sight were leading the way.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 84.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The dumb whose tongues He had loosed, shouted the loudest hosannas.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 84.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The cripples whom He had healed leaped for joy, and were most active in breaking the palm branches and waving them before Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 84.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Widows and orphans were exalting the name of Jesus for His works of mercy to them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 84.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The loathsome lepers who had been cleansed by a word, spread their garments in the way.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 84.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Those who had been raised from the dead by the life-giving voice of the Saviour were there.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 84.11 (Ellen Gould White)
content: And Lazarus, whose body had seen corruption in the grave, but who was now enjoying the strength of glorious manhood, was with the happy throng that escorted the Saviour to Jerusalem.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 85.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As new numbers were added to the throng, they caught the inspiration of the hour, and joined in the shouts that echoed and re-echoed from hill to hill and from valley to valley:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 85.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Hosanna to the Son of David! Blessed is He that cometh in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the highest.” Matthew 21:9.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 85.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Many Pharisees witnessed this scene, and were displeased. They felt that they were losing the control of the people. With all their authority they tried to silence them; but their threats and appeals only increased the enthusiasm.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 85.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Finding that they could not control the people, they pressed through the crowd to where Jesus was, and said to Him: “Master, rebuke Thy disciples.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 85.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They declared that such a tumult was unlawful, and would not be permitted by the rulers.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 85.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus said, “I tell you that, if these should hold their peace, the stones would immediately cry out.” Luke 19:39, 40.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 85.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This scene of triumph was of God's own appointing; it had been foretold by the prophets, and no earthly power could stop it. The work of God will ever go forward, in spite of all that man may do to hinder it or tear it down.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 85.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As the procession came to the brow of the hill overlooking Jerusalem, the full splendor of the city met their view.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 85.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The vast multitude hushed their shouts, spellbound by the sudden vision of beauty. All eyes turned upon the Saviour, expecting to see in His countenance the admiration which they themselves felt.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 86.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus halted, and a cloud of sorrow gathered upon His countenance, and the multitude were astonished to see Him burst into an agony of weeping.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 86.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Those who surrounded the Saviour could not understand His grief; but He wept for the city that was doomed.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 86.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: It had been the child of His care, and His heart was filled with anguish as He realized that it would soon be made desolate.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 86.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Had her people given heed to Christ's teaching, and received Him as the Saviour, Jerusalem would have “stood forever.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 86.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: She might have become the queen of kingdoms, free in the strength of her God-given power.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 86.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: There would then have been no armed soldiers waiting at her gates, no Roman banners waving from her walls.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 86.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: From Jerusalem the dove of peace would have gone to all nations. She would have been the crowning glory of the world.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 86.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But the Jews had rejected their Saviour; they were about to crucify their King. And when the sun should set that night, the doom of Jerusalem would be forever sealed. (About forty years afterward, Jerusalem was utterly destroyed and burned with fire by the Roman army.)

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 86.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Reports had come to the rulers that Jesus was nearing the city with a vast company of followers. They went out to meet Him, hoping to scatter the throng. With a show of much authority they asked: “Who is this?” Matthew 21:10.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 86.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The disciples, filled with the Spirit of inspiration, answered: “Adam will tell you, ‘It is the Seed of the woman that shall bruise the serpent's head.’

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 87.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Ask Abraham. He will tell you, ‘It is Melchisedek, King of Salem, King of Peace.’

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 87.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Jacob will tell you, ‘He is Shiloh of the tribe of Judah.’

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 87.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Isaiah will tell you, ‘Immanuel, Wonderful, Counsellor, the mighty God, the everlasting Father, the Prince of Peace.’

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 87.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Jeremiah will tell you, ‘The Branch of David, the Lord, our righteousness.’

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 87.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Daniel will tell you, ‘He is the Messiah.’

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 87.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Hosea will tell you, ‘He is the Lord God of Hosts, the Lord is His memorial.’

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 87.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “John the Baptist will tell you, ‘He is the Lamb of God that taketh away the sin of the world.’

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 87.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “The great Jehovah has proclaimed from His throne, ‘This is My beloved Son.’

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 87.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “We, His disciples, declare, ‘This is Jesus, the Messiah, the Prince of Life, the Redeemer.’

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 87.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “And even the prince of the power of darkness acknowledges Him, saying, ‘I know Thee who Thou art, the Holy One of God!’”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 89 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 14—“Take These Things Hence”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 89.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The next day Christ entered the temple. Three years before, He had found men buying and selling in the outer court, and had rebuked them and driven them out.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 89.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Now as He came again to the temple, He found the same traffic still carried on. The court was filled with cattle, sheep, and birds. These were sold to those who wished to offer sacrifice for their sins.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 89.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Extortion and robbery were practiced by those engaged in this traffic. So great was the babel of sounds from the court, that it seriously disturbed the worshipers within.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 89.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ stood on the steps of the temple, and again His piercing gaze swept over the court. All eyes were turned toward Him. The voices of the people and the noise of the cattle were hushed. All looked with astonishment and awe upon the Son of God.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 89.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The divine flashed through the human, and gave Jesus a dignity and glory He had never manifested before. The silence became almost unbearable.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 90.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At last He said in clear tones, and with a power that swayed the people like a mighty tempest:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 90.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “It is written, My house is the house of prayer: but ye have made it a den of thieves.” Luke 19:46.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 90.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: With still greater authority than He had manifested three years before, He commanded:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 90.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Take these things hence.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 90.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Once before the priests and rulers of the temple had fled at the sound of this voice. Afterward they were ashamed of their fear. They felt that they would never flee in this way again.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 90.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Yet they were now more terrified, and in greater haste than before to obey His command, and they rushed from the temple, driving their cattle before them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 90.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Soon the court was filled with people who brought their sick to be healed by Jesus. Some were dying. These afflicted ones felt their distressing need.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 90.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They fixed their eyes imploringly upon the face of Christ, fearing to see there the severity which had driven out the buyers and sellers. But they saw in His face only love and tender pity.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 90.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus kindly received the sick, and disease and suffering fled at the touch of His hand. He tenderly gathered the children in His arms, soothed their fretful cries, banished sickness and pain from their little forms, and handed them back, smiling and healthy, to their mothers.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 90.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: What a scene to greet the priests and rulers as they cautiously made their way back to the temple! They heard the voices of men, women, and children praising God.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 90.11 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They saw the sick healed, the blind restored to sight, the deaf receive their hearing, and the lame leap for joy.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 91.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The children took the lead in these rejoicings. They repeated the hosannas of the day before, and waved palm branches before the Saviour. The temple echoed and re-echoed with their shouts:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 91.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Hosanna to the Son of David:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 91.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Blessed is He that cometh in the name of the Lord!” Matthew 21:9.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 91.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Behold, thy King cometh unto thee: He is just, and having salvation.” Zechariah 9:9.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 91.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The rulers tried to silence the shouts of the happy children, but all were filled with joy and praise for the wonderful works of Jesus, and they would not be silenced.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 91.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The rulers then turned to the Saviour, hoping that He would command them to cease. They said to Him:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 91.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Hearest Thou what these say?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 91.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus replied, “Yea; have ye never read, Out of the mouth of babes and sucklings Thou hast perfected praise?” Matthew 21:16.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 91.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The blessed privilege of heralding the birth of Christ and forwarding His work in the earth had been refused by the haughty rulers of the people.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 91.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: His praises must be sounded; and God chose the children to do it. Had the voices of these rejoicing children been silenced, the very pillars of the temple would have cried out in the Saviour's praise.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 93 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 15—At the Passover Supper

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 93.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Children of Israel ate the first Passover supper at the time of their release from bondage in Egypt.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 93.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: God had promised to set them free. He had told them that the first-born son in every family of the Egyptians was to be slain.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 93.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He had told them to mark their own door posts with the blood of the slain lamb, that the angel of death might pass them by.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 93.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The lamb itself they were to roast and eat at night, with unleavened bread and with bitter herbs, which represented the bitterness of their slavery.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 93.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When they ate the lamb, they must be all ready for a journey. They must have their shoes on their feet, and their staves in their hands.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 93.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They did as the Lord had said, and that very night the king of Egypt sent them word that they might go free. In the morning they started on their way to the land of promise.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 93.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: So every year, the same night on which they left Egypt, all the Israelites kept the feast of the Passover at Jerusalem. At this feast each family had a roasted lamb, with bread and bitter herbs, as their forefathers had in Egypt. And they told their children the story of God's goodness in freeing His people from slavery.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 94.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The time had now come when Christ was to keep the feast with His disciples, and He told Peter and John to find a place, and make ready the Passover supper.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 94.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: A great many people came to Jerusalem at this time, and those who lived in the city were always ready to give a room in their houses for visitors to keep the feast.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 94.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour told Peter and John that when they had gone into the street, they would meet a man carrying a pitcher of water. Him they were to follow, and they were to go into the house where he went. And they were to say to the good man of that house:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 94.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “The Master saith unto thee, Where is the guestchamber, where I shall eat the Passover with My disciples?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 94.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This man would then show them a large upper room furnished for their needs; there they were to prepare the Passover supper. And it all happened just as the Saviour had told them it would.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 94.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At the Passover supper the disciples were alone with Jesus. The time they spent with Him at these feasts had always been a time of joy; but now He was troubled in spirit.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 94.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At last He said to them in tones of touching sadness:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 94.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “With desire I have desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 94.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: There was sweet wine on the table, and He took a cup of it, “and gave thanks, and said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 95.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Take this, and divide it among yourselves: for I say unto you, I will not drink of the fruit of the vine, until the kingdom of God shall come.” Luke 22:11, 15, 17, 18.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 95.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: This was the last time that Christ was to keep the feast with His disciples. It was really the last Passover that was ever to be kept. For the lamb was slain to teach the people about Christ's death; and when Christ, the Lamb of God, should be slain for the sins of the world, there would be no need of slaying a lamb to represent His death.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 95.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When the Jews sealed their rejection of Christ by putting Him to death, they rejected all that gave to this feast its value and significance. Henceforth its observance by them was a worthless form.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 95.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As Christ joined in the Paschal service, there was before His mind the scene of His last great sacrifice. He was now in the shadow of the cross, and the pain was torturing His heart. He knew all the anguish that awaited Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 95.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He knew the ingratitude and cruelty that would be shown Him by those He had come to save. But it was not of His own suffering that He thought. He pitied those who would reject their Saviour and lose eternal life.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 95.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: And the thought of His disciples was uppermost in His mind. He knew that after His own suffering was over, they would be left to struggle in the world.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 95.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He had much to tell them that would be a stay to their hearts when He should walk no more with them. Of these things He had hoped to speak at this their last meeting before His death.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 95.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But He could not tell them now. He saw that they were not ready to listen.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 95.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: There had been a contention among them. They still thought that Christ was soon to be made king, and each of them wanted the highest place in His kingdom. So they had jealous and angry feelings toward one another.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 97.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: There was another cause of trouble. At a feast it was the custom for a servant to wash the feet of the guests, and on this occasion preparation had been made for the service. The pitcher of water, the basin, and the towel were there, ready for the feet-washing. But no servant was present, and it was the disciples’ part to perform it.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 97.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But each of the disciples thought that he would not be a servant to his brethren. He was not willing to wash their feet. So, in silence they had taken their places at the table.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 97.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus waited awhile to see what they would do. Then He Himself rose from the table. He girded Himself with the towel, poured water into the basin, and began to wash the disciples’ feet. He had been grieved by their contention, but He did not reprove them by sharp words. He showed His love by acting as a servant to His own disciples. When He had finished, He said to them:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 97.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “If I then, your Lord and Master, have washed your feet; ye also ought to wash one another's feet. For I have given you an example that ye should do as I have done to you.” John 13:14, 15.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 97.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In this way Christ taught them that they ought to help one another. Instead of seeking the highest place for himself, each should be willing to serve his brethren.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 97.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour came into the world to work for others. He lived to help and save those who are needy and sinful. He wants us to do as He did.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 97.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The disciples were now ashamed of their jealousy and selfishness. Their hearts were filled with love for their Lord and for one another. Now they could give heed to Christ's teaching.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 98.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As they were still at the table, Jesus took bread, and gave thanks, and broke it, and gave to them, saying, “This is My body which is given for you: this do in remembrance of Me.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 98.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Likewise also the cup after supper, saying, This cup is the New Testament in My blood, which is shed for you.” Luke 22:19, 20.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 98.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Bible says, “As often as ye eat this bread, and drink this cup, ye do show the Lord's death till He come.” 1 Corinthians 11:26.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 98.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The bread and the wine represent the body and the blood of Christ. As the bread was broken, and the wine poured out, so on the cross Christ's body was broken, and His blood shed to save us.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 98.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: By eating the bread and drinking the wine, we show that we believe this. We show that we repent of our sins, and that we receive Christ as our Saviour.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 98.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As the disciples sat at the table with Jesus, they saw that He still seemed greatly troubled. A cloud settled on them all, and they ate in silence.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 98.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At last Jesus spoke and said, “Verily I say unto you, that one of you shall betray Me.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 98.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The disciples were grieved and amazed at these words. Each began to look into his heart to see if there was any shadow of an evil thought against their Master.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 98.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: One after another they asked, “Lord, is it I?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 98.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Judas alone remained silent. This drew the eyes of all to him. When he saw that he was observed, he too asked, “Master, is it I?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 99.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: And Jesus solemnly replied, “Thou hast said.” Matthew 26:21, 22, 25.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 99.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus had washed the feet of Judas, but this had not caused him to love the Saviour more. He was angry that Christ should do a servant's work. Now he knew that Christ would not be made king, and he was the more determined to betray Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 99.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When he saw that his purpose was known, even this did not cause him to fear. In anger he quickly left the room, and went away to carry out his wicked plan. The going of Judas was a relief to all present. The Saviour's face lighted, and at this the shadow was lifted from the disciples.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 99.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ now talked for some time with His disciples. He was going to His Father's house, He said, to make a place ready for them, and He would come again to take them to Himself.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 99.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He promised to send the Holy Spirit to be their teacher and comforter while He was gone. He told them to pray in His name, and their prayers would surely be answered.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 99.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He then prayed for them, asking that they might be kept from evil, and might love one another as He had loved them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 99.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus prayed for us as well as for the first disciples. He said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 99.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Neither pray I for these alone, but for them also which shall believe on Me through their word; that they all may be one; as Thou, Father, art in Me, and I in Thee, that they also may be one in us: that the world may believe that Thou hast sent Me, ... and hast loved them, as Thou hast loved Me.” John 17:20-23.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 101 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 16—In Gethsemane

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 101.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour's life on earth was a life of prayer. Many were the hours He spent alone with God. Often did He send up His earnest petitions to His heavenly Father. Thus He received strength and wisdom to sustain Him in His work, and to keep Him from falling under the temptations of Satan.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 101.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: After eating the Passover supper with His disciples, Jesus went with them to the garden of Gethsemane, where He often went to pray. As He walked, He talked with them, and taught them; but as they neared the garden, He became strangely silent.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 101.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: All His life, Jesus had lived in the presence of His Father. The Spirit of God had been His constant guide and support. He always gave God the glory for His works on earth, and said, “I can of Mine own self do nothing.” John 5:30.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 101.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: We can do nothing of ourselves. It is only by relying on Christ for all our strength that we can overcome, and do His will on earth. We must have the same simple, childlike trust in Him that He had in His Father. Christ said, “Without Me ye can do nothing.” John 15:5.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 102.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The terrible night of agony for the Saviour began as they neared the garden. It seemed that the presence of God, which had been His support, was no longer with Him. He was beginning to feel what it was to be shut out from His Father.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 102.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ must bear the sins of the world. As they were now laid upon Him, they seemed more than He could endure. The guilt of sin was so terrible, He was tempted to fear that God could no longer love Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 102.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As He felt the awful displeasure of the Father against evil, the words were forced from Him, “My soul is exceeding sorrowful, even unto death.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 102.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Near the gate of the garden, Jesus had left all His disciples except Peter, James, and John, and He had gone into the garden with these three. They were His most earnest followers, and had been His closest companions. But He could not bear that even they should witness the suffering He was to endure. He said to them:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 102.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Tarry ye here, and watch with Me.” Matthew 26:38.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 102.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He went a short distance from them, and fell prostrate upon the ground. He felt that by sin He was being separated from the Father. The gulf between them appeared so broad, so black, so deep, that He shuddered before it.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 102.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ was not suffering for his own sins, but for the sins of the world. He was feeling the displeasure of God against sin as the sinner will feel it in the great judgment day.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 102.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In His agony, Christ clung to the cold ground. From His pale lips came the bitter cry, “O My Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from Me; nevertheless not as I will, but as Thou wilt.” Matthew 26:39.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 103.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: For an hour Christ bore this terrible suffering alone. Then He came to the disciples, hoping for some word of sympathy. But no sympathy awaited Him, for they were asleep. They awoke at the sound of His voice, but they hardly knew Him, His face was so changed by anguish. Addressing Peter, He said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 103.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Simon, sleepest thou? Couldest not thou watch one hour?” Mark 14:37.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 103.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Just before He bent His footsteps to the garden, Christ had said to the disciples, “All ye shall be offended because of Me this night.” They had given Him the strongest assurance that they would go with Him to prison and to death. And poor, self-sufficient Peter had added, “Although all shall be offended, yet will not I.” Mark 14:27, 29.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 103.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But the disciples trusted to themselves. They did not look to the Mighty Helper as Christ had counselled them to do. So when the Saviour was most in need of their sympathy and prayers, they were found asleep. Even Peter was sleeping.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 103.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: And John, the loving disciple who had leaned upon the breast of Jesus, was asleep. Surely the love of John for his Master should have kept him awake. His earnest prayers should have mingled with those of his loved Saviour in the time of His great agony. The Redeemer had spent whole nights in praying for His disciples, that their faith might not fail in the hour of trial. Yet they could not remain awake with Him even one hour.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 103.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Had Christ now asked James and John, “Can ye drink of the cup that I drink of? and be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with?” they would not have answered so readily as they did before, “We can.” Mark 10:38, 39.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 104.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour's heart was filled with pity and sympathy at the weakness of His disciples. He feared that they could not endure the test which His suffering and death would bring upon them.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 104.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Yet He did not sternly reprove them for their weakness. He thought of the trials that were before them, and said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 104.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Watch and pray, that ye enter not into temptation.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 104.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He made an excuse for their failure in duty toward Him: “The spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.” Matthew 26:41. What an example of the tender, loving pity of the Saviour!

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 104.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Again the Son of God was seized with superhuman agony. Fainting and exhausted, He staggered back, and prayed as He had prayed before:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 104.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “O My Father, if this cup may not pass away from Me, except I drink it, Thy will be done.” Matthew 26:42.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 104.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The agony of this prayer forced drops of blood from His pores. Again He sought the disciples for sympathy, and again He found them sleeping. His presence aroused them. They looked upon His face with fear, for it was stained with blood. They could not understand the anguish of mind which His face expressed.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 104.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The third time He sought the place of prayer. A horror of great darkness overcame Him. He had lost the presence of His Father. Without this, He feared that in His human nature He could not endure the test.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 104.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The third time He prays the same prayer as before. Angels long to bring relief, but it may not be. The Son of God must drink this cup, or the world will be lost forever. He sees the helplessness of man. He sees the power of sin. The woes of a doomed world pass in review before Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 105.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He makes the final decision. He will save man at any cost to Himself. He has left the courts of Heaven, where all is purity, happiness, and glory, to save the one lost sheep, the one world that has fallen by transgression, and He will not turn from His purpose. His prayer now breathes only submission:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 105.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “If this cup may not pass away from Me, except I drink it, Thy will be done.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 105.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour now falls dying to the ground. No disciple is there, to place his hand tenderly beneath his Master's head, and bathe that brow, marred indeed more than the sons of men. Christ is alone; of all the people there are none with Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 105.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But God suffers with His Son. Angels behold the Saviour's agony. There is silence in Heaven. No harp is touched. Could men have viewed the amazement of the angelic host as in silent grief they watched the Father separating His beams of light, love, and glory from His beloved Son, they would better understand how offensive in His sight is sin.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 105.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: A mighty angel now comes to the side of Christ. He lifts the head of the divine sufferer upon his bosom, and points toward Heaven. He tells Him that He has come off victor over Satan. As the result, millions will be victors in His glorious kingdom.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 105.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: A heavenly peace rests upon the Saviour's blood-stained face. He has borne that which no human being can ever bear; for He has tasted the sufferings of death for every man.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 106.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Again Christ sought His disciples, and again He found them sleeping. Had they remained awake, watching and praying with their Saviour, they would have received help for the trial before them. Missing this, they had no strength in their hour of need.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 106.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Looking sorrowfully on them, Christ said, “Sleep on now, and take your rest: behold, the hour is at hand, and the Son of man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 106.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Even as He spoke these words, He heard the footsteps of the mob in search of Him, and said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 106.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Rise, let us be going: behold, he is at hand that doth betray Me.” Matthew 26:45, 46.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 107 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 17—The Betrayal and Arrest

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 107.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: No traces of His recent suffering were to be seen as the Saviour stepped forth to meet His betrayer. Standing in advance of His disciples, He asked the mob:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 107.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Whom seek ye?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 107.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They answered, “Jesus of Nazareth.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 107.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus replied, “I am He.” John 18:4, 5.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 107.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As Jesus spoke these words, the angel who had recently ministered to Him moved between Him and the mob. A divine light illuminated the Saviour's face, and a dovelike form overshadowed Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 107.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In the presence of this divine glory the murderous throng could not stand for a moment. They staggered back. The priests, elders, and soldiers dropped as dead men to the ground.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 107.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The angel withdrew, and the light faded away. Jesus could have escaped, but He remained, calm and self-possessed. His disciples were too much amazed to utter a word.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 109.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Roman soldiers soon started to their feet. With the priests and Judas, they gathered about Christ. They seemed ashamed of their weakness, and fearful that He would escape. Again the question was asked by the Redeemer: “Whom seek ye?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 109.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Again they answered, “Jesus of Nazareth.” The Saviour then said, “I have told you that I am He: if therefore ye seek Me, let these [pointing to His disciples] go their way.” John 18:7, 8.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 109.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In this hour of trial, Christ's thoughts were for His beloved disciples. He did not wish to have them suffer, even though He must go to prison and to death.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 109.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Judas, the betrayer, did not forget the part he was to act. He came to Jesus, and kissed Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 109.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus said to him, “Friend, wherefore art thou come?” Matthew 26:50. His voice trembled as He added, “Betrayest thou the Son of man with a kiss?” Luke 22:48.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 109.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: These gentle words should have touched the heart of Judas; but all tenderness and honor seemed to have left him. Judas had yielded himself to the control of Satan. He stood boldly before the Lord, and was not ashamed to give Him up to the cruel mob.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 109.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ did not refuse the traitor's kiss. In this He gave us an example of forbearance, love, and pity. If we are His disciples, we must treat our enemies as He treated Judas.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 109.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The murderous throng became bold as they saw Judas touch the form which had so recently been glorified before their eyes. They now laid hold of the Saviour, and bound those hands that had ever been employed in doing good.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 109.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The disciples did not think that Christ would allow Himself to be taken. They knew that the power which could strike down the mob as dead men could keep them helpless till Christ and His companions should escape.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 110.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: They were disappointed and indignant as they saw the cords brought forward to bind the hands of Him whom they loved. Peter, in his anger, rashly drew his sword, and tried to defend his Master. But he only cut off an ear of the high priest's servant.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 110.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When Jesus saw what was done, He released His hands, though held firmly by the Roman soldiers, and saying, “Suffer ye thus far” (Luke 22:51), He touched the wounded ear, and it was instantly made whole.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 110.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He then said to Peter, “Put up again thy sword into his place: for all they that take the sword shall perish with the sword. Thinkest thou that I cannot now pray to My Father, and He shall presently give Me more than twelve legions of angels? But how then shall the Scriptures be fulfilled, that thus it must be?” Matthew 26:52-54. “The cup which My Father hath given Me, shall I not drink it?” John 18:11.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 110.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ then turned to the chief priests and the captains of the temple, who were with the mob, and said, “Are ye come out as against a thief, with swords and with staves to take me? I was daily with you in the temple teaching, and ye took Me not: but the Scriptures must be fulfilled.” Mark 14:48, 49.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 110.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The disciples were offended when they saw that the Saviour made no effort to deliver Himself from His enemies. They blamed Him for not doing so. They could not understand His submission to the mob, and, terror-stricken, they forsook Him and fled.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 110.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ had foretold this desertion. “Behold,” He had said, “the hour cometh, yea, is now come, that ye shall be scattered, every man to his own, and shall leave Me alone: and yet I am not alone, because the Father is with Me.” John 16:32.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 113 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 18—Before Annas, Caiaphas, and the Sanhedrin

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 113.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus was followed from the garden of Gethsemane by the hooting mob. He moved painfully, for His hands were tightly bound, and He was closely guarded.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 113.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He was taken first to the house of Annas, who had formerly been the high priest, but whose place was then filled by his son-in-law, Caiaphas. The wicked Annas had requested that he might be the first to see Jesus of Nazareth a bound captive. He hoped to draw from Him some evidence by which to secure His condemnation.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 113.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: With this in view he questioned the Saviour with regard to His disciples and His teachings. Christ answered:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 113.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “I spake openly to the world; I ever taught in the synagogue, and in the temple, whither the Jews always resort; and in secret have I said nothing.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 113.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Then, turning upon the questioner, He said, “Why askest thou Me? Ask them which heard Me, what I have said.” John 18:20, 21.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 113.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The priests themselves had set spies to watch Christ and report His every word. Through these spies they knew of His sayings and of His works at every gathering of the people He had attended. The spies had sought to entrap Him in His words, that they might find something by which to condemn Him. So the Saviour said, “Ask them which heard Me.” Go to your spies. They have heard what I have said. They can tell you what My teaching has been.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 114.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The words of Christ were so searching and pointed that the priest felt that his prisoner was reading his very soul.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 114.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But one of the servants of Annas, thinking that his master was not treated with proper respect, struck Jesus in the face saying: “Answerest Thou the high priest so?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 114.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: To this Jesus mildly said: “If I have spoken evil, bear witness of the evil: but if well, why smitest thou Me?” John 18:22, 23.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 114.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Christ could have summoned legions of angels from Heaven to His aid. But it was a part of His mission to endure in His humanity all the taunts and insults that men might heap upon Him.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 114.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: From the house of Annas, the Saviour was taken to the palace of Caiaphas. He was to be tried before the Sanhedrin, and while its members were being called together, Annas and Caiaphas again questioned Him, but they gained no advantage.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 114.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When the members of the Sanhedrin had assembled, Caiaphas took his seat as the president. On each side were the judges; before them stood the Roman soldiers guarding the Saviour; back of these was the accusing mob.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 114.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Caiaphas then bade Jesus work one of His mighty miracles before them. But the Saviour gave no sign that He heard a word. Had He responded by even one soul-searching look, such as He gave the buyers and sellers in the temple, the whole murderous throng would have been compelled to flee from His presence.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 115.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Jews were at this time subject to the Romans, and were not allowed to punish any one with death. The Sanhedrin could only examine the prisoner, and pass judgment to be ratified by the Roman authorities.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 115.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: To accomplish their wicked purpose, they must find something against the Saviour that would be regarded as criminal by the Roman governor. They could secure abundant evidence that Christ had spoken against the Jewish traditions and many of their ordinances. It was easy to prove that He had denounced the priests and scribes, and that He had called them hypocrites and murderers. But this would not be listened to by the Romans, for they themselves were disgusted with the pretensions of the Pharisees.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 115.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Many charges were brought against Christ, but either the witnesses disagreed, or the evidence was of such a nature that it would not be accepted by the Romans. They tried to make Him speak in answer to their accusations, but He appeared as if He had not heard them. The silence of Christ at this time had been thus described by the prophet Isaiah:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 115.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “He was oppressed, and He was afflicted, yet He opened not His mouth: He is brought as a lamb to the slaughter, and as a sheep before her shearers is dumb, so He openeth not His mouth.” Isaiah 53:7.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 115.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The priests began to fear that they would fail of obtaining any evidence which they could bring against their prisoner before Pilate. They felt that one last effort must be made. The high priest raised his right hand toward Heaven, and addressed Jesus in the form of a solemn oath:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 116.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “I adjure Thee by the living God, that Thou tell us whether Thou be the Christ, the son of God.” Matthew 26:63.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 116.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour never denied His mission or His relation to the Father. He could remain silent to personal insult, but He ever spoke plainly and decidedly when His work or Sonship to God was called in question.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 116.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Every ear was bent to listen, and every eye was fixed upon Him as He answered: “Thou hast said.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 116.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In the custom of those days this was the same as answering, “Yes,” or, “It is as thou hast said.” This was the strongest form of an affirmative answer. A heavenly light seemed to illuminate the pale countenance of the Saviour as He added:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 116.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Nevertheless I say unto you, Hereafter shall ye see the Son of man sitting on the right hand of power, and coming in the clouds of Heaven.” Matthew 26:64.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 116.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: In this statement the Saviour presented the reverse of the scene then taking place. He pointed forward to the time when He will occupy the position of supreme Judge of Heaven and earth. He will then be seated upon the Father's throne, and from His decisions there will be no appeal.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 116.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He brought before His hearers a view of that day, when, instead of being surrounded and abused by a riotous mob, He will come in the clouds of Heaven with power and great glory. Then He will be escorted by legions of angels. Then He will pronounce sentence upon His enemies, among whom will be that same accusing throng.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 117.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As Jesus spoke the words declaring Himself to be the Son of God, and Judge of the world, the high priest rent his robe, as if to show his horror. He lifted his hands toward Heaven, and said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 117.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “He hath spoken blasphemy; what further need have we of witnesses? Behold, now ye have heard His blasphemy. What think ye?”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 117.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The judges answered, “He is guilty of death.” Matthew 26:65, 66.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 117.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: It was contrary to the Jewish law to try a prisoner by night. Though the condemnation of Christ had been determined, there must be a formal trial by day.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 117.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Jesus was taken to the guard room, and there suffered mockery and abuse from the soldiers and the rabble.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 117.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At daybreak He was again brought before His judges, and the final sentence of condemnation was pronounced.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 117.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: A satanic fury then took possession of the leaders and the people. The roar of voices was like that of wild beasts. They made a rush for Jesus, crying, “He is guilty, put Him to death!” and had it not been for the soldiers, He would have been torn in pieces. But Roman authority interposed, and by force of arms restrained the violence of the mob.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 117.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Priests, rulers, and the rabble joined in abusing the Saviour. An old garment was thrown over His head; and His persecutors struck Him in the face, saying:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 117.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “Prophesy unto us, Thou Christ, Who is he that smote Thee?” Matthew 26:68.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 117.10 (Ellen Gould White)
content: When the garment was removed, one of the mocking throng spat in the Saviour's face.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 117.11 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The angels of God faithfully recorded every insulting look, word, and act against their beloved Commander. One day those base men who scorned and spat upon the calm, pale face of Christ will look upon it in its glory, shining brighter than the sun.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 119 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Chapter 19—Judas

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 119.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Jewish rulers had been anxious to get Jesus into their power, but for fear of raising a tumult among the people they had not dared to take Him openly. So they had sought some one who would secretly betray Him, and had found in Judas, one of the twelve disciples, the man who would do this base act.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 119.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Judas had naturally a strong love for money, but he had not always been wicked and corrupt enough to do such a deed as this. He had fostered the evil spirit of avarice until it had become the ruling motive of his life, and he could now sell his Lord for thirty pieces of silver (about $17.00), the price of a slave. (Exodus 21:28-32.) He could now betray the Saviour with a kiss in Gethsemane.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 119.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: But he followed every step of the Son of God, as He went from the garden to the trial before the Jewish rulers. He had no thought that the Saviour would allow the Jews to kill Him, as they had threatened to do.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 119.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: At every moment he expected to see Him released and protected by divine power, as had been done in the past. But as the hours went by, and Jesus quietly submitted to all the indignities that were heaped upon Him, a terrible fear came to the traitor, that he had indeed betrayed his Master to His death.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 121.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: As the trial drew to a close, Judas could endure the torture of his guilty conscience no longer. All at once there rang through the hall a hoarse voice, which sent a thrill of terror to the hearts of all present:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 121.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “He is innocent. Spare Him, O Caiaphas. He has done nothing worthy of death!”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 121.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The tall form of Judas was seen pressing through the startled crowd. His face was pale and haggard, and large drops of sweat stood on his forehead. Rushing to the throne of judgment, he threw down before the high priest the pieces of silver that had been the price of his Lord's betrayal.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 121.4 (Ellen Gould White)
content: He eagerly grasped the robe of Caiaphas, and begged him to release Jesus, declaring that He had done no wrong. Caiaphas angrily shook him off, and said with scorn:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 121.5 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “What is that to us? See thou to that.” Matthew 27:4.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 121.6 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Judas then threw himself at the Saviour's feet. He confessed that Jesus was the Son of God, and begged Him to deliver Himself from His enemies.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 121.7 (Ellen Gould White)
content: The Saviour knew that Judas did not really repent for what he had done. The false disciple feared that punishment would come upon him for his terrible deed; but he felt no real sorrow because he had betrayed the spotless Son of God.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 121.8 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Yet Christ spoke to him no word of condemnation. He looked with pity upon Judas, and said:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 121.9 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “For this hour came I into the world.”

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 122.1 (Ellen Gould White)
content: A murmur of surprise ran through the assembly. With amazement they beheld the forbearance of Christ toward His betrayer.

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 122.2 (Ellen Gould White)
content: Judas saw that his entreaties were in vain, and he rushed from the hall, crying:

refcode_long: The Story of Jesus, p. 122.3 (Ellen Gould White)
content: “It is too late! It is too late!”
